metadata.title: Chemically deposited nano grain composed MoS2 thin films for supercapacitor application

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Chemically deposited nano grain composed MoS2 thin films for supercapacitor application
R.B. Pujari, A.C. Lokhande, A.R. Shelke, J.H. Kim, C.D. Lokhande
PII: S0021-9797(16)30903-1 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2016.11.026 Reference: YJCIS 21754
To appear in: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Received Date: 12 October 2016 Revised Date: 7 November 2016 Accepted Date: 7 November 2016
Please cite this article as: R.B. Pujari, A.C. Lokhande, A.R. Shelke, J.H. Kim, C.D. Lokhande, Chemically deposited nano grain composed MoS2 thin films for supercapacitor application, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science (2016), doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2016.11.026
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Chemically deposited nano grain composed MoS2 thin
films for supercapacitor application
R.B. Pujari a , A.C. Lokhande b , A.R. Shelke a , J.H. Kim b# , C.D. Lokhande c*
a Thin Film Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Shivaji University, Kolhapur, 416 004 (M.S), India. b Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju 500-757, South Korea. c Center for Interdisciplinary Research, D.Y. Patil University, Kolhapur 416 006.
CO-CORRESPONDING AUTHOR FOOTNOTE # Prof. J. H. Kim Tel.: +82 62 530 1702, Fax: +82 62 530 1699. Email Address: jinhyeok@chonnam.ac.kr
CORRESPONDING AUTHOR FOOTNOTE * Prof. Chandrakant D. Lokhande Tel.: +91 231 2609225, Fax: +91 231 2609233. E-mail Address: l_chandrakant@yahoo.com

sections.heading: Abstract:
sections.text: Low temperature soft chemical synthesis approach is employed towards MoS2 thin film preparation on cost effective stainless steel substrate. 3-D semispherical nano-grain composed surface texture of MoS2 film is observed through FE-SEM technique. Electrochemical supercapacitor performance of MoS2 film is tested from cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic charge discharge (GCD) techniques in 1M aqueous Na2SO4 electrolyte. Specific capacitance (Cs) of 180 Fg -1 with CV cycling stability of 82% for 1,000 cycles is achieved. Equivalent series resistance (Rs) of 1.78 Ωcm -2 observed through Nyquist plot shows usefulness of MoS2 thin film for charge conduction in supercapacitor application. Key words: Chemical synthesis, Galvanostatic charge-discharge, Gravimetric energy density, MoS2, Supercapacitor, Thin film.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Supercapacitors, also known as electrochemical capacitors, have gathered growing
interest of researchers in the era of miniaturization of devices [1]. These have fascinating properties of high energy density than traditional capacitor, higher power density than battery, long life (10 6 charge discharge cycles), environmental protection, low toxicity than batteries, low cost etc. In the past few decades, different materials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [2], reduced graphene oxide (RGO) [3], metal oxides [4], conducting polymers [5] are tested for supercapacitor application. Also, RGO/MnO2 [6], NiO/CNTs [7], polyaniline/CNTs [8] etc composites, are prepared for further improvement in the electrochemical supercapacitor performance of bare materials. Recently metal sulfides such as CoS2 [9], NiS [10], MnS [11], CuS [12], MoS2 [13] etc have received attention for their intensive use in supercapacitors.
Nowadays molybdenum sulfide (MoS2) has been studied for various applications such as
piezoelectrics [14], sensors [15], electrocatalysts [16], hydrogen storage [17], as an electrode for Li-ion battery [18], supercapacitor electrode [19] etc. One of its merits over metal oxide and graphene oxide is their higher conductivity [20]. Moreover, molybdenum based materials (such as MoO3, MoO2, MoS2, etc) exhibit multiple valence states and rich chemistry, which makes them a promising candidate for electrochemical applications. MoS2 is a member of layered chalcogenide material family having special structural properties of interest for the application in supercapacitor [20]. In the molybdenum sulfide compound, molybdenum (Mo) and sulfur (S) atoms are bonded in a chain fashion to form a MoS2 layer [21]. Consecutive layers of MoS2 are weakly bonded to each other by a Van der wall force of attraction. Interlayer space between consecutive layers is of angstrom order and can be utilized for intercalation and de-intercalation process of electrolyte ions in the context of charge storage application [22].
Till now, studies on chemical synthesis and supercapacitive properties of MoS2 film have
been rare. As a literature review, Krushnamurthy et al [23] reported 92.85 Fg -1 specific capacitance (Cs) of chemically prepared MoS2 nanostructure. Further, Wang et al [24] reported 142 Fg -1
Cs of MoS2 nanospheres. Low crystallinity and layers aggregation of MoS2 are
responsible factors for moderate supercapacitive performance of MoS2. Therefore, the effort has been made to improve performance of MoS2. Some strategies can be worked out to improve performance of material such as binder free film preparation or MoS2/CNT and/or MoS2/RGO composite synthesis or porous nanostructure material designing by optimizing preparative parameters etc. Out of these, binder free film preparation of MoS2 has advantages of good conductivity at the interface of metallic current collector and material which ultimately reduces the diffusion path length of electrons and improves electron transfer between material and current collector. Present work reports soft chemical synthesis of binder free MoS2 film and its electrochemical supercapacitive performance tested in 1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte. 2. Experimental:

sections.heading: 2.1 MoS2 thin film preparation:
sections.text:
Soft chemical method was employed to prepare MoS2 film. Analytical reagent (AR)
grade ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24), sulfuric acid and thioacetamide chemicals were purchased from Thomas Baker company pvt ltd Mumbai. Chemicals were used without further purifications. A 20 ml solution of 0.005 M ammonium heptamolybdate is prepared in double distilled water (DDW) and 5 ml 1 M sulfuric (H2SO4) acid was added to it under constant magnetic stirring. Finally, 0.1 M 20 ml ultrasonically treated thioacetamide solution in DDW was added and resultant solution was rigorously stirred for 5 min. Further, prepared solution in glass beaker along with vertically placed stainless steel (SS) substrate was maintained at 303 K
in constant temperature water bath for 5 h. Initially, blue color solution turned to brown on heating and precipitate formation was started in the solution. After 5 h uniform beautiful brown color thin film was formed on SS substrate.

sections.heading: 2.2. Material characterizations:
sections.text:
MoS2 thin film was characterized for surface microstructure evaluation from FE-SEM
work station and crystal structure evaluation using X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern obtained using D2 phaser X-ray powder diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Further elemental valence states in 343 K MoS2 thin film was analyzed with X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) using ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer microprobe. N2 adsorption desorption isotherm was measured by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) measurement using Quantachrome, Model-NOVA 1000E. Electrochemical measurements were performed in freshly prepared 1.0 M Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte with 8 channels battery cycler (Wonatech WBCS-3000 model) using regular three electrode cell system having reference and counter electrodes as a standard calomel electrode (SCE) and platinum substrate, respectively.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion:
sections.text:
Thin film development in soft chemical method involves four crucial steps, which are followed in general by metal chalcogenide materials. Nucleation sites, aggregates of nuclei, coalescence of aggregates and film growth steps are followed one after other sequentially to produce uniform homogeneous thin film [25]. MoS2 thin film production using reaction mixture explained in experimental part on any kind of substrate can be possible by proposed chemical reactions given below, Initially, addition of H2SO4 solution to ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24) results into formation of ammonium molybdate as follows,
(NH4)6Mo7O24 + 4H2SO4 7(NH4)2MoO4 + 4(NH4)2SO4 + 4H2O (1)
Molybdate molecule further dissociates in to molybdenum ion as follows in the solution,
(NH4)2MoO4 (NH4) 2+ + (MoO4) 2-
(2)
Further, thioacetamide (CH3SNH2) solution in DDW produces H2S as follows,
CH3SNH2 + H2O CH3ONH2 + H2S (3)
Addition of CH3SNH2 solution to ammonium molybdate solution produces MoS2 particles in bulk of solution because of excess ionic product over solubility product. MoS2 film formation on the substrate is possible either (1) via ion by ion condensation or (2) by adsorption of colloidal MoS2 particles, as shown in following reaction (4) [25].
4(NH4)2MoO4 + 3H2SO4 + 9H2S 4MoS2 + 4(NH4)2SO4 + 12H2O (4)
Fig. 1 (A and B) shows FE-SEM images of MoS2 film at two different magnifications
(5,000X and 50, 000X). Large numbers of MoS2 nano grains of average size 50 to 70 nm are observed in 50,000X magnification image Fig. 1(B). These nano grains are connected to each other to form clusters. These clusters are distributed throughout whole surface of film as observed in Fig. 1(B). Interconnected 3-D Nano size semispherical particles effectively enhance surface area and maximum accessibility of material. Uniform MoS2 nano-particles are illustrated in Fig. 1(A and B), except few large size (500 nm to 1µm) MoS2 cluster formations. These clusters interrupting uniformity of film may be attributed to favorable active sites formation for nucleation and growth of adsorbing MoS2 molecules on the substrate surface. These kinds of surface texture help to improve electrochemical performance of material in perspective of supercapacitor application.
TEM images of MoS2 are presented in Fig. 1(C and D). Fig. 1(C) shows MoS2
nanograins of average diameter size of 50 to 90 nm. The obtained nano-grain size from TEM
image is consistent with the FE-SEM image observed in Fig. 1(B), in which 3-D semispherical nanograins are observed with the size of 50-70 nm. Fig. 1(D) is the magnified region of small square part of TEM image in Fig. 1(C). Fig. 1(D) shows nonspecific ordered arrangement of atoms, which indicates that, soft chemically prepared MoS2 nanograins are amorphous/poor crystalline in nature. This result supports to amorphous/poor crystalline nature result obtained from XRD technique
X- ray diffraction pattern of MoS2 film does not show any significant diffraction peak in
Fig. 2. Peak indexed with ‘∆’ are originated due to stainless steel substrate. Present work reports soft chemical synthesis approach for MoS2 film preparation from chemical bath deposition method, which includes low temperature (303 K) deposition. At low temperature, internal energy required to obtain specific crystal structure orientation of material is not sufficiently available. Thus, low internal energy treatment produces non-crystalline/amorphous arrangement of atoms in the material. Therefore, in the XRD results of MoS2 film, x ray diffraction peaks are not observed, which indicates that, MoS2 thin film is amorphous/poor crystalline in nature.
Further, such an amorphous or poor crystalline material is usually formed with a low
lattice energy and it improves the utilization ratio of electrode materials by allowing an easy deintercalation process in the respect of electrochemical performance of material.
X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) is employed for compositional analysis of
MoS2. This technique finds number of elements presents on the solid surface as well as chemical state of an element. Fig. 3(A and B) explores XPS curves of MoS2 film. High intense peak at 227.73 eV denotes binding energy of 3d5/2 electrons ejected from Mo atom indicating molybdenum in the Mo 4+
state and subsequent peak at 234.56 eV is due to 3d3/2 electrons of
Mo2S6 phase of molybdenum sulfide in consistent with literature [26]. Further Fig. 3(B) explains
S 2- state of sulfur due to existence of electronic reflection at about 164 eV and consecutive reflection about 170 eV indicates presence of oxide phase due to air exposition of film before characterization [26].
Nitrogen (N2) adsorption-desorption isothermal measurements were carried out at
different relative pressures to determine surface area and pore size distribution of material. Fig. 3(C) explores N2 adsorption and desorption type IV isotherm of MoS2 sample and inset shows volume and pore size relation. The most of pore volume is distributed through 3 to 44 nm mesopores shown as inset of Fig. 3(D). BET specific surface area of sample calculated from adsorption-desorption curve and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) plot is 19.01 m 2 g -1 with average 18 nm pore diameter. The obtained BET specific surface area of MoS2 is greater than reported by Thangappan et al [27] of bare MoS2 nanosheets. Low surface area obtained by Thangappan et al [27] for MoS2 nanosheets structure is due to aggregation of nanosheets on one another which effectively reduces surface area of material. The obtained 19.01 m 2 g -1 BET specific surface area of MoS2 reduces electrochemical performance of material. Electrochemical performance of material can be improved by preparing MoS2/graphene composite, where, graphene derivative supply large surface area for the electrochemically active pseudocapacitive MoS2 particles. Hence, surface area and consequently electrochemical performance of MoS2 can be improved ultimately by preparing MoS2/graphene composite.
Electrochemical properties of MoS2 film are tested from typical cyclic voltammetry (CV)
and galvanostatic charge discharge (GCD) techniques in 1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte within 0 to -1.1 V/SCE operating potential window.
Cyclic voltammetry measurements of MoS2 film are performed to determine specific
capacitance (Cs) and volumetric capacitance (Cv) of material. Fig. 4(A) shows CV curves of
MoS2 film obtained for different scan rates. Area of CV curve as well as enhanced cathodic and anodic peak current values with increasing scan rate suggest ideal capacitive nature of MoS2. Further, Each CV curve exhibits quasi rectangular shape without any sharp redox peaks, which suggests typical electrochemical double layer (EDLC) nature of MoS2 as observed in Fig. 4(B). Additionally, slight deviation of CV shape from its rectangular behavior infers weak pseudocapacitive behavior present in action due to reversible reactions (i.e. Mo 3+ to Mo 4+ change in oxidation state of Mo). Pseudocapacitance originates from electrolyte ions intercalation and de-intercalation through MoS2 interlayer spacing provided by MoS2 adjacent layers weakly bonded by Van der waal forces, which enhances effective electrochemical performance [26]. Absence of redox peaks in CV curves infers fast charging/discharging of electrode. Reversible electrochemical reaction takes place at the surface of MoS2 due to Na + ion adsorption and desorption can be expressed as follows [26],
MoS2 + Na + + e - ↔ MoS2Na (5)
where, equation (5) represents Na + reaction on adsorption at the MoS2 film surface. Specific (Cs) and volumetric (Cv) capacitances of MoS2 film are calculated using following equations (6) and (7), respectively.

where, I(v) is current response of the film for operating potential window (v1-v2) at scan rate (s), m is mass and ρ is density of material. Specific and volumetric capacitance values of material for different scan rates are shown in Fig. 4(B). 180, 143, 122, 94 and 77 Fg -1
Cs values are obtained
for 5, 10, 20, 50 and 100 mVs -1
scan rates showing good rate capability of MoS2. Further, highest
910.8 Fcm -3 Cv is calculated for 5 mVs -1 CV scan rate shown in Fig. 4(B). Wang et al [13] also, prepared MoS2 nanostructures using hydrothermal method and obtained highest specific capacitance of 155 Fg -1 which is less than obtained in present work. It may be due to less potential window (0.4 V/SCE) obtained by them. Similarly, the obtained Cv value in present work is greater than 330 Fcm -3
reported by Choudhary et al [22]. Less Cv obtained by choudhary
et al [22] may be due to very small 0.2 V/SCE operating potential window for compact island structure of MoS2.
Electrochemical supercapacitive properties of MoS2 film are further tested using
galvanostatic charge discharge technique to understand more about electrochemical behavior. MoS2 film is charged and discharged for four different current densities presented in Fig 4(C). Cs and Cv capacitances from charge discharge profiles are obtained using following expressions.
vm
tI Cs

  ,
vV
tI Cv

  (8)
where, ∆t is discharging time interval, I is applied constant current rate at charging of material, V is volume, m is mass of active material and ∆v is potential window. Highest Cs and Cv capacitances of 137 Fg -1 and 691.5 Fcm -3 are obtained for 1.1 mAcm -2 current rate as shown in Fig. 4(D). Krishnamoorthy et al [23] prepared MoS2 nanostructures using hydrothermal synthesis approach and achieved 106 Fg -1 specific capacitance. The less capacitance obtained by Krishnamoorthy et al [23] than obtained in present work may be due to low potential window of (0.7 V/SCE) nanostructured MoS2. Various supercapacitive parameters obtained in present work are compared with the literature data in Table 1. Ragone plot of MoS2 film is presented in Fig. 5(A) for four different current rates. Highest energy density (E) of 23 Whkg -1 for the power density (P) of 2.1 kWkg -1 is obtained in Fig. 5(A). Similarly, Fig. 5(A) displays highest
volumetric energy density (Ev) of 116 Whcm -3 for 10.2 kWcm -3 volumetric power density (Pv). The obtained E and P values in present work are greater than reported by Krishnamoorthy et al (7.25 Whkg -1 ) [23] Li et al (2.7 Whkg -1 ) [28] and Karade et al (14.58 Whkg -1 ) [29]. But, energy density obtained in present work is less than reported by Krishnamoorthy et al [20], which may be due to large Cs and active potential window of MoS2 nanosheets obtained by them.
Consecutive CV cycles of MoS2 film are performed in 1M Na2SO4 for testing long term
working ability and 82 % capacitance is retained after 1,000 CV cycles as observed in Fig. 4(B). CV cycling stability of material can be enhanced by preparing MoS2/graphene or MoS2/CNT composite. Thangappan et al [7] reported 74.7 % capacitive retention for 1,000 CV cycles of hydrothermally prepared MoS2 nanosheets. In the same work, capacitance retention was improved by Thangappan et al [7] to 89.6 % for 1,000 cycles making MoS2/graphene composite.
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) technique is a fundamental tool which
can extracts various electrochemical parameters such as equivalent series resistance (Rs) charge transfer resistance (Rct) and Warburg diffusion resistance of electrode and electrolyte system which ultimately affect the electrochemical performance of material. Impedance of MoS2 film is measured in 1 M Na2SO4 through Nyquist plot within a frequency range of 100 kHz to 100 mHz with an AC amplitude of 0.01V as shown in Fig. 4(C). Inset of Fig. 4(C) exhibits magnified part of Nyquist plot. The first intercept of curve to real axis known as Rs and diameter of semicircle encompassed in mid higher frequency refers to Rct of electrode-electrolyte system. Rs is made up of electronic and ionic resistances. Electronic resistance is associated with interparticle and intraparticle resistance of material and interfacial resistance between current collector and electrode material. Ionic resistance arises due to electrolyte and diffusion resistance through the pores. Rs and Rct of 1.8 Ωcm -2 and 20.82 Ωcm -2 are observed in higher frequency and mid higher
frequency region, respectively. Further, extended part of Nyquist curve in lower frequency region suggests supercapacitive nature of MoS2 film. 4. Conclusions: Binder free MoS2 film is successfully deposited on cost effective stainless steel substrates using single step soft chemical method. Amorphous nano-grain composed MoS2 thin film shows highest specific capacitance (Cs) of 180 Fg -1 at 5 mVs -1 CV scan rate and delivers gravimetric energy density (E) of 23 Whkg -1 at 2.1 kWkg -1 power density (P). This results suggests chemically deposited MoS2 film is a promising electrode material for high efficiency supercapacitors.
